content: SECTION 1. TRAFFICKING IN COUNTERFEIT MARKS. The "Stop Counterfeiting in Manufactured Goods Act" aims to address the significant economic impact of counterfeit goods in the United States. Counterfeiting costs the economy millions in tax revenue and thousands of jobs annually. Various industries, including auto parts, electrical appliances, medicines, and clothing, are affected by counterfeit products. The "Stop Counterfeiting in Manufactured Goods Act" aims to combat the trafficking of counterfeit goods, which is linked to terrorist organizations and poses a threat to public health and safety. Strong domestic criminal remedies against counterfeiting will enable the US to negotiate better anticounterfeiting provisions in international agreements. The "Stop Counterfeiting in Manufactured Goods Act" targets the trafficking of counterfeit goods, including items like labels, patches, stickers, and packaging, to prevent confusion and deception. Property used in committing violations will be subject to forfeiture to the United States. The court, in imposing sentence on a person convicted of an offense under this section, shall order forfeiture of any property obtained from the offense, property used in committing the offense, and any counterfeit articles. When a person is convicted of an offense under this section, the court shall order forfeiture of any property obtained from the offense, property used in committing the offense, and any counterfeit articles. The forfeiture procedures are governed by the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970, with the court ordering the destruction of any forfeited article bearing a counterfeit mark. Restitution to the owner of the mark and other victims may also be ordered. The term 'victim' in this context refers to the meaning given in section 3663A(a)(2). Subsection (e)(1) is amended to include a definition of a spurious mark used in connection with trafficking goods or services. The section may be cited as the "Protecting American Goods and Services Act of 2005." It amends the definition of "traffic" in relation to counterfeit goods or services in the United States Code. The term "financial gain" now includes the receipt or expected receipt of anything of value.
